description:
Hippoglossus stenolepis, commonly known as the Pacific halibut, is a large, flatfish species found in the northern Pacific Ocean. As a member of the family Pleuronectidae, it exhibits the typical characteristics of a flatfish, with both eyes located on the same side of its flattened body.

The Pacific halibut is known for its impressive size, with the largest individuals reaching up to 2.5 meters in length and weighing over 300 kilograms. This species is an important commercial and recreational fishery, valued for its firm, white flesh and delicate flavor.

Anatomically, the Pacific halibut has a distinctive elongated and laterally compressed body shape, which aids in its ability to burrow into the seafloor and camouflage itself against the substrate. Its coloration is typically dark brown or olive-green on the upper side, with a lighter, white underside, helping it blend in with the ocean floor.

Ecologically, the Pacific halibut is a predatory species, feeding on a variety of prey, including other fish, crustaceans, and mollusks. It plays a crucial role in the marine ecosystem, both as a top predator and as a valuable food source for various marine predators, including seals, sea lions, and larger fish species.

Conservation efforts for the Pacific halibut have been ongoing, as the species is susceptible to overfishing due to its slow growth and late maturation. Sustainable management practices, such as catch limits and size restrictions, have been implemented to ensure the long-term sustainability of this ecologically and economically important species.
